entities.name: BUILDING A ROCKET: A STEP-BY-STEP GUIDE
entities.description: An essay that outlines the process of building a rocket, from initial design to launch

entities.name: ROCKET
entities.description: A vehicle designed to travel through space, often used for scientific research and exploration

entities.name: SCIENCE PROJECT
entities.description: A project typically undertaken by students to explore scientific principles and concepts

entities.name: PAYLOAD
entities.description: The cargo or equipment that a rocket carries into space

entities.name: ORBIT
entities.description: The path that a spacecraft or satellite follows around a planet or other celestial body

entities.name: AERODYNAMICS
entities.description: The study of how air moves around objects, particularly in the context of designing efficient and stable rockets

entities.name: STABILITY
entities.description: The ability of a rocket to maintain a consistent and controlled flight path

entities.name: WEIGHT DISTRIBUTION
entities.description: The arrangement of mass within a rocket to ensure optimal performance and stability

entities.name: ALUMINUM
entities.description: A lightweight and durable material often used in the construction of rocket bodies

entities.name: CARBON FIBER
entities.description: A strong and lightweight composite material used in the construction of rocket bodies

entities.name: FIBERGLASS
entities.description: A composite material used for its strength and lightweight properties in rocket construction

entities.name: FUEL SYSTEM
entities.description: The system that provides the necessary energy for the rocket's propulsion

entities.name: PROPULSION SYSTEM
entities.description: The system that generates thrust to lift the rocket and propel it into space

entities.name: GUIDANCE SYSTEMS
entities.description: Sophisticated electronics that control the rocket's flight path and ensure a safe and successful launch

entities.name: ELECTRONICS
entities.description: Components such as sensors, actuators, and onboard computers that control the rocket's functions

entities.name: TEST FLIGHTS
entities.description: Flights conducted to verify the rocket's stability and performance before the final launch

entities.name: LAUNCH
entities.description: The event where the rocket is sent into the sky, marking the culmination of the building process

entities.name: STUDENT
entities.description: An individual, often young, who is learning and may be involved in building a rocket as part of a science project

entities.name: HOBBYIST
entities.description: An individual who builds rockets as a personal interest or pastime

entities.name: ASPIRING AEROSPACE ENGINEER
entities.description: An individual who is interested in pursuing a career in aerospace engineering and may build rockets as part of their learning and development

entities.name: ELECTRONIC COMPONENTS
entities.description: Components such as sensors, actuators, and onboard computers that are essential for the control and guidance of the rocket

entities.name: NOSE CONE
entities.description: The front part of the rocket designed to reduce air resistance and protect the payload

entities.name: PARACHUTES
entities.description: Devices used to safely return the rocket or its components back to the ground after launch

entities.name: GROUND TESTS
entities.description: Tests conducted on the ground to ensure the rocket's systems are functioning correctly before the final launch

entities.name: SAFETY REGULATIONS
entities.description: Rules and guidelines that must be followed to ensure the safe construction and launch of rockets

entities.name: SCIENCE AND ENGINEERING PRINCIPLES
entities.description: The fundamental concepts and theories that underpin the design and construction of rockets

entities.name: FLIGHT PATH
entities.description: The trajectory that a rocket follows during its flight, controlled by the guidance system

entities.name: CRITICAL COMPONENTS
entities.description: Key parts of the rocket that are essential for its operation, including the propulsion system, electronics, and structural components
